https://prez.dev/description.@value: A wellhead (WH) is the component at the surface of an oil or gas well that provides the structural and pressure-containing interface for the drilling and production equipment. Depth is commonly referenced from the valve or outlet point from which samples are extracted.

The point or level from which heights and depths are measured and referenced to for an entity or activity. Typically these are expressed relative to a common global or regional reference datum such as the Australian Height Datum (AHD) or can be related to local reference systems. Specific emphasis is placed on elevation references used by resource exploration and drilling programs, whereby depths are measured relative to local reference datums or specific parts of a borehole/drilling platform. Concepts in this vocabulary include both reference datums (e.g. mean sea level) and how depths are expressed relative to them (e.g. mean sea level height).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: In the resources industry,the depth of any point in a borehole/drillhole/well is the measurement of the distance between a reference point or elevation and that point. It is the most common method of reference for locations in a borehole. In the minerals industry, it usually refers to the distance from the drill collar. Inthe oil industry, 'depth' also refers to the location itself. By extension, depth can refer to locations below, or distances from, a reference point or elevation, even when there is no well. In that sense, depth is a concept related toelevation, albeit in the opposite direction. Depth in a borehole is not necessarily measured vertically or along a straight line. Because boreholes are not always drilled vertically, there may be two 'depths' for every given point in a borehole: themeasured depth(MD)measured along the path of theborehole, and thetrue vertical depth(TVD), the absolute vertical distance between thereference datumand the point in theborehole. In perfectly vertical holes, the TVD equals the MD; otherwise, the TVD is less than the MD measured from the same datum. Common references used are reduced level (RL), drill collar, ground level (GL),drilling rigfloor (DF),rotary table(RT),kelly bushing(KB or RKB) andmean sea level(MSL).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: An umbrella term for resources industry concepts related to the reference points from which depth is measured in boreholes/wells.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: In the resources industry,the depth of any point in a borehole/drillhole/well is the measurement of the distance between a reference point or elevation and that point. It is the most common method of reference for locations in a borehole. In the minerals industry, it usually refers to the distance from the drill collar. Inthe oil industry, 'depth' also refers to the location itself. By extension, depth can refer to locations below, or distances from, a reference point or elevation, even when there is no well. In that sense, depth is a concept related toelevation, albeit in the opposite direction. Depth in a borehole is not necessarily measured vertically or along a straight line. Because boreholes are not always drilled vertically, there may be two 'depths' for every given point in a borehole: themeasured depth(MD)measured along the path of theborehole, and thetrue vertical depth(TVD), the absolute vertical distance between thereference datumand the point in theborehole. In perfectly vertical holes, the TVD equals the MD; otherwise, the TVD is less than the MD measured from the same datum. Common references used are reduced level (RL), drill collar, ground level (GL),drilling rigfloor (DF),rotary table(RT),kelly bushing(KB or RKB) andmean sea level(MSL).

In the mineral resources industry, 'drill collar' is referred to as the location (in an x, y, z coordinate system) as well as the start point of a borehole from which depths are measured. Drill collars are tubular pieces of material, usually metal or plastic, to aid in keeping the hole entry from collapsing.

The drill floor (DF), also known as derrick floor, is the working area in which the rig crew conducts drilling operations, and is often used as a reference point for downhole/depth measurements. Depth measurements are commonly referenced to the DF, with notations like 2538 m DF or 2358 m BDF, indicating 2538 m below the drill/derrick floor.

The height or level of the natural ground or the level of the exposed surface of the ground. This may be at the Earth's surface (ground surface) or below (e.g. bottom of a mine shaft or floor of an open pit). Ground level can be used as a reference point for vertical measurements (especially in drilling), without reference to any equipment used during drilling (cf. rotary table, kelly bushing).

In drilling, the kelly bushing (KB) or rotary kelly bushing (RKB) is an adapter that serves to connect the rotary table to the kelly (a long square or hexagonal steel bar with a hole drilled through the middle for a fluid path). Depth measurements are commonly referenced to the KB, such as 2538 m KB, meaning 2538 metres below the kelly bushing (BKB).
Mudline as referenced in subsea operations refers to the seafloor or water bottom.
The point at depth where the pre-collar hole ends and the diamond tail (i.e. diamond drilling) starts, and from which the length/depth of the diamond core is referenced.

The revolving or spinning section of the drill floor that provides power to turn the drillstring in a clockwise direction (as viewed from above), often used as a starting point for measurement of borehole depth (below rotary table or BRT).
